G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a request to modify an existing custody and parenting‑time order of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court regarding a minor child who is domiciled in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a request to modify an existing custody and parenting‑time order of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court regarding a minor child who is domiciled in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a request to modify an existing custody and parenting‑time order of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court regarding a minor child who is domiciled in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the existing custody judgment was entered in this Court and the minor child resides within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the existing custody judgment was entered in this Court and the minor child resides within the jurisdiction of this Court.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting‑time order upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The case deals with modification of alimony and child support under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37, not modification of legal or physical custody or parenting time. The court discusses the standard for modifying a support order (material change in circumstances and the needs/benefit of the children), but it never addresses custody or visitation standards or a best‑interests test in that context. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modifying custody or parenting‑time orders.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28….”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting‑time order upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is reviewing an initial custody award in a divorce judgment and focuses solely on the requirement that custody determinations be based on the welfare/best interests of the child. It does not discuss modification standards, changes in circumstances, or the prerequisites for altering an existing custody or parenting‑time order. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific two‑part standard for modification of prior custody orders.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed."

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.proposition: Courts recognize that a child’s maturation and changing developmental needs can constitute a material change warranting review of prior custody or parenting‑time orders.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion does involve a modification proceeding that includes custody, but it does not discuss a child’s maturation or changing developmental needs as a material change in circumstances. The custody discussion turns on the parents’ inability to communicate and the lack of specific findings on best interests, not on the child’s developmental stage or maturation as a basis for modifying custody or parenting time. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Courts recognize that a child’s maturation and changing developmental needs can constitute a material change warranting review of prior custody or parenting‑time orders.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses initial custody, joint custody versus sole custody, and the scope of visitation, but it does not address modification of prior custody or parenting‑time orders based on a child’s maturation or changing developmental needs. There is no language about a later material change in circumstances, nor about revisiting an earlier order as children grow older. The focus is on best interests and parental conflict at the time of the divorce trial, not on subsequent developmental changes as a ground for modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.” (quoting Jenkins v. Jenkins).

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: The correction of that predicate is, in itself, a material change in circumstances.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The case holds that the mother’s remarriage, which occurred after the divorce, is itself a material and substantial change in circumstances; the court corrects the trial judge’s mistaken predicate that it was not a post‑divorce change. The proposition that “the correction of that predicate is, in itself, a material change in circumstances” misstates the opinion. The opinion treats the *fact of remarriage* as the material change, not the appellate court’s correction of the trial judge’s legal error.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce. The judge’s contrary treatment contributed to his devaluation of the mother’s marriage as a factor to be considered, and may well have had a significant effect on his over-all treatment of the case.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: While a child’s preference is not controlling, the Court may consider the reasonable preferences of a child of sufficient age and maturity as one factor in the best‑interests analysis.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly notes that the child, Caleb, expressed a preference to live primarily with his mother, and the court explains that while such a preference is not dispositive of custody, it is a factor that should be considered. The court cites Ardizoni v. Raymond for the proposition that a child’s stated preference is not controlling, yet acknowledges it as relevant to assessing his best interests. This directly aligns with the claimed proposition about considering the reasonable preferences of a sufficiently mature child as one factor in the best‑interests analysis.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "In addition, we note that Caleb expressed to the guardian ad litem at the outset of the investigation his preference to reside primarily with his mother, and he reiterated this preference at the conclusion of the investigation, shortly before trial. Although not dispositive of the custody issue, Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738-739 (1996), these factors, at the very least, suggest that Caleb might quickly readjust to living with his mother during the week, and visiting his father on weekends and during part of each school vacation."

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: While a child’s preference is not controlling, the Court may consider the reasonable preferences of a child of sufficient age and maturity as one factor in the best‑interests analysis.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses only the overarching best‑interests standard and the judge’s discretion in custody matters; it does not mention, analyze, or rely on the child’s preference, nor does it articulate any rule about considering a child’s wishes at a certain age or maturity. Although the judge interviewed the child, the court’s reasoning and holding are framed entirely in terms of welfare and do not state that a child’s reasonable preference is a factor. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about considering a mature child’s preference.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”

*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.proposition: Their shared recognition that the old schedule is no longer workable further evidences a material change in circumstances.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contempt/enforcement decision focused on ability to pay alimony, consideration of potential income, other assets, and a contractual bar on modification. It does not discuss parenting or visitation schedules, nor any concept of a “shared recognition” that an existing schedule is unworkable as evidence of a material change in circumstances. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.relevant_excerpt: On June 11, 1987, the parties, both represented by counsel, executed a separation agreement which made comprehensive provisions for alimony, child support and property division. The agreement was to “survive as an independent agreement” after their divorce. ... The Probate Court judge’s finding was reasonable. She read the language of their 1989 agreement to preclude future reduction based upon change in Phillip’s employment. His present effort to achieve modification was, thus, barred by the limitation imposed by the separation agreement itself.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Any modification of custody or parenting time must serve the Child’s best interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The court squarely states that under the removal statute, “upon cause shown” means that removal must be in the child’s best interests, and then explains that the central question is how those best interests are to be determined when changing the custodial arrangement by permitting out‑of‑state (or out‑of‑country) relocation. The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that the child’s best interests are the paramount concern in deciding whether to alter custody/visitation via relocation, which is consistent with the proposition that any modification must serve the child’s best interests, even though the case is specifically about removal rather than all conceivable custody modifications.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.proposition: Any modification of custody or parenting time must serve the Child’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the removal/relocation decision—and thus the modification of the existing shared custody/parenting-time arrangement—under G.L. c. 208, § 30 as turning on whether removal is in the children’s best interests. The court repeatedly states that “cause shown” under the statute means a showing that removal is in the child’s best interests and upholds the lower court’s decision because it found the move would not serve those best interests. This directly supports the proposition that a modification impacting custody/parenting time (here, relocation) must serve the child’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … After…trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal…was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court.”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.proposition: In determining best interests, Massachusetts courts consider, among other factors: the child’s age and developmental needs; the quality of the child’s relationship with each parent; each parent’s ability to provide for the child’s emotional, educational, and physical needs; the stability of each home; and the desirability of maintaining continuity and minimizing disruptive transitions.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies a flexible, holistic “best interests” standard and mentions stability, developmental needs, attachments, and home environment, but it does not set out or synthesize the specific multifactor list stated in the proposition. The factors in the proposition (age, relationship with each parent, each parent’s ability to meet needs, stability of each home, continuity/minimizing transitions) can be inferred from the court’s discussion, but they are not articulated as a canonical list or test. Thus the case is consistent with, but does not clearly *establish*, the detailed proposition as a governing standard.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development… [T]he best interests standard mandated by G. L. c. 210, § 3, is ‘a flexible one,’ and the weight to be accorded its several considerations… ‘will vary with the circumstances.’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.proposition: In determining best interests, Massachusetts courts consider, among other factors: the child’s age and developmental needs; the quality of the child’s relationship with each parent; each parent’s ability to provide for the child’s emotional, educational, and physical needs; the stability of each home; and the desirability of maintaining continuity and minimizing disruptive transitions.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard and emphasizes stability, continuity, primary caregiver status, and maintaining existing satisfactory arrangements. However, it does not set out, list, or otherwise articulate a multi-factor test including the child’s age and developmental needs, the quality of the relationship with each parent, or an itemized list of emotional, educational, and physical needs and home stability as in the proposition. While the judge’s findings touch some of these ideas in application, the case is not authority for that specific enumerated factor test and is instead focused on the statutory requirements of G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and the importance of preserving stable caregiving arrangements.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child. … If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child…”

*Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454, 461 (.proposition: A modified schedule that includes overnights with Father can be structured around the Child’s school schedule to ensure that his educational needs, homework, and rest are fully met, consistent with the Court’s obligation to prioritize the Child’s welfare over the convenience of either parent.
*Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454, 461 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is about jurisdiction and forum-selection in an interstate custody dispute, not about structuring parenting time or overnights around a child’s school schedule. While the court reiterates that the child’s welfare is the paramount consideration in custody matters, it does not discuss parenting schedules, overnights, homework, rest, or coordinating time with a school schedule. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition regarding structuring an overnight schedule with Father around the child’s schooling needs.
*Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454, 461 (.relevant_excerpt: “As we indicated in Aufiero, the child ‘was not chargeable with the misconduct of her mother in failing to return her . . . and ought not to be compelled to suffer for it. Her welfare is the paramount consideration.’ Aufiero, supra at 153. The misconduct of the parent may, nevertheless, adversely affect the welfare of the child.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The modification sought aligns with the public policy of the Commonwealth favoring active participation of both fit parents in the upbringing of their children, so long as it is consistent with the child’s best interests.
